57. With regard to the spectrum of <u>hydrogen <\u>
we first refer to former observations. The spectrum 
one of us obtained by sending the discharge 
of Ruhmkorff’s small induction coil through 
one of the highly evacuated spectral tubes,
constructed by Mr. Geissler, shows only three 
bright lines, which he denoted by H[alpha], H[beta] and 
H[gamma]. The beautiful red light of the ignited 
rarefied gas, divided into these three bright 
lines, even after having passed through the 
four prisms of Steinheil’s spectral apparatus, remains highly concentrated. At a magni 
fying power of 72, the three bright lines 
or small bands, thus obtained, are well 
defined. Their apparent breadth is equal to 
the breadth of the slit, they approach gra 
dually to mathematical lines. Hence we 
conclude that, under the above mentioned 
conditions the length of wave of the light , consti 
tuting each of the three Hydrogen lines is 
constant and remains so, if expanded into 
bands. In referring the middle lines of such 
bands to the middle line of the direct image 
of the slit, we obtain its angle of refraction.
It was proposed to employ these middle 
lines instead of Fraunhofer’s dark lines 
of the solar spectrum in determining the 
indices of refraction. + This proceding has 
since been proved to be very expedient. +
Landolt. Ueber die Brechungs 
exponenten flussigen homologen 
Verbindungen. Pogg. Ann <s>CV<\s>
CXVII p 353
